snippet: Deaths from gastrointestinal infections more than doubled in the United States from 1997 to 2007, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention announced Wednesday.
abstract: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention announces that deaths from gastrointestinal infections more than doubled in the United States from 1997 to 2007; states that the two leading causes are Clostridium difficile, bacterium which people often contract in hospitals and nursing homes, and the highly contagious norovirus.
lead_paragraph: Deaths from gastrointestinal infections more than doubled in the United States from 1997 to 2007, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention announced Wednesday.
